Package uk.ac.leeds.ccg.agdt.generic.io

Class Generic_IO

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leeds.ccg.agdt.generic.core.Generic_Object
uk.ac.leeds.ccg.agdt.generic.io.Generic_IO
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class Generic_IO
extends Generic_Object
Class of methods for helping with reading and writing (primarily) to/from file.
See Also:
Serialized Form

      FileInputStream

    • delete

      public long[] delete​(java.io.File file)
      Attempts to delete file from the file system. This does no block other reads or writes to the files system while it is executing and it will only succeed in deleting empty directories.
      Parameters:
      file - File.
      Returns:
      long[] result where: result[0] is the number of directories deleted; result[1] is the number of files deleted.

      Parameters:

      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If IOException encountered.

    • setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1

      public void setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1​(java.io.StreamTokenizer st)
      Sets the syntax of st as follows: 
      
 <ul>
 <li>st.wordChars( '0', '0' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '1', '1' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '2', '2' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '3', '3' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '4', '4' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '5', '5' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '6', '6' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '7', '7' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '8', '8' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '9', '9' );</li>
 </ul>
      Parameters:
      st - StreamTokenizer that has syntax set.

    • setStreamTokenizerSyntax1

      public void setStreamTokenizerSyntax1​(java.io.StreamTokenizer st)
      Sets the syntax of st as follows: 
      
 <ul>
 <li>st.resetSyntax();</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ',', ',' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '"', '"' );</li>
 <li>setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1(st);</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '.', '.' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '-', '-' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '+', '+' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'a', 'z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'A', 'Z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '\t', '\t' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ' ', ' ' );</li>
 <li>st.eolIsSignificant( true );</li>
 </ul>
      Parameters:
      st - StreamTokenizer thats syntax is set.

    • setStreamTokenizerSyntax2

      public void setStreamTokenizerSyntax2​(java.io.StreamTokenizer st)
      Sets the syntax of st as follows: 
      
 <ul>
 <li>st.resetSyntax();</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '"', '"' );</li>
 <li>setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1(st);</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '.', '.' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '-', '-' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '+', '+' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'e', 'e' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'E', 'E' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '\t', '\t' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ' ', ' ' );</li>
 <li>st.eolIsSignificant( true );</li>
 </ul>
      Parameters:
      st - StreamTokenizer thats syntax is set

    • setStreamTokenizerSyntax3

      public void setStreamTokenizerSyntax3​(java.io.StreamTokenizer st)
      Sets the syntax of st as follows: 
      
 <ul>
 <li>st.resetSyntax();</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ',', ',' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '"', '"' );</li>
 <li>setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1(st);</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '.', '.' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '-', '-' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '+', '+' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'a', 'z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'A', 'Z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '\t', '\t' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ' ', ' ' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '_', '_' );</li>
 <li>st.eolIsSignificant( true );</li>
 </ul>
      Parameters:
      st - StreamTokenizer thats syntax is set

    • setStreamTokenizerSyntax5

      public void setStreamTokenizerSyntax5​(java.io.StreamTokenizer st)
      Sets the syntax of st as follows: 
      
 <ul>
 <li>st.resetSyntax();</li>
 <li>st.wordChars(',', ',' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '"', '"' );</li>
 <li>setStreamTokenizerSyntaxNumbersAsWords1(st);</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '.', '.' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '-', '-' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '+', '+' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'a', 'z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( 'A', 'Z' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '\t', '\t' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ' ', ' ' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( ':', ':' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '/', '/' );</li>
 <li>st.wordChars( '_', '_' );</li>
 </ul>
      Parameters:
      st - StreamTokenizer thats syntax is set

    • getObjectDir

      public java.io.File getObjectDir​(java.io.File dir, long id, long n, long range)
      Parameters:
      dir - File directory.
      id - The ID of the Object to be stored.
      n - The maximum number of objects to be stored.
      range - The number of objects stored per directory.
      Returns:
      File directory in which object with a_ID is (to be) stored within dir.

    • initialiseArchive

      public java.io.File initialiseArchive​(java.io.File dir, long range, boolean exists) throws java.io.IOException
      Initialises a directory in directory and returns result.
      Parameters:
      dir - File directory which is the base of this archive.
      range - For specifying the number of leafs in a directory and the number of directories in any directory.
      exists - This is a declaration that the user knows whether or not the archive already exists. If exist == true, then the archive is expected to exist, if it does not, then an IOException is thrown. However if it does already exist, it's form is tested using range. If the form is fine, then the highest archive leaf is returned otherwise an IOException is thrown.
      Returns:
      File that is the highest archive leaf for a newly created archive, or the highest archive leaf for an existing archive.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If exist == true, then the archive is expected to exist and have the correct form, if it does not, then an IOException is thrown.

    • testArchiveIntegrity

      public java.io.File testArchiveIntegrity​(java.io.File dir) throws java.io.IOException
      Parameters:
      dir - The base of the archive to test.
      Returns:
      The archive highest leaf obtained from getArchiveHighestLeafFile(java.io.File)
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If the archive lacks integrity.

      range - long
      n - The maximum number of objects to be stored.

      Returns:
      long

    • getArchiveLeafFilesSet

      public java.util.HashSet<java.io.File> getArchiveLeafFilesSet​(java.io.File dir)
      For returning all the leaf file elements in a branch of an archive as a HashSet<File>. An archive has directories such as ./0_99 which store leaves such as ./0_99/0 and ./0_99/10. The archive may have considerable depth such that an archive leaf is stored for example in ./0_999999/0_9999/0_99/0. The leaves are the directories at the end of the tree branches that contain directories that do not have an underscore in the filename
      Parameters:
      dir - File directory.
      Returns:
      a HashSet<File> containing all files in the directory. The directory is regarded as a directory that possibly contains other directories in a branching tree with paths that are expected to end eventually in one or more files. All such files are returned in the result. The result is null if the directory is empty.

    • getArchiveLeafFilesMap

      public java.util.TreeMap<java.lang.Long,​java.io.File> getArchiveLeafFilesMap​(java.io.File dir)
      Potentially slow and could be speeded up by going through the file tree branch by branch.
      Parameters:
      dir - File.
      Returns:
      TreeMap

    • getNumericallyOrderedFiles

      public java.util.TreeMap<java.lang.Long,​java.io.File> getNumericallyOrderedFiles​(java.io.File[] files)
      Parameters:
      files - The files are expected to be from an archive or to be numerically ordered. These are specially names. Either they have a name that can be resolved as a long. Or they have a name containing a Generic_Strings.symbol_underscore with components that can be resolved as long (e.g. 0_99, 100_199).
      Returns:
      TreeMap

    • getFilePathLength

      public int getFilePathLength​(java.io.File f) throws java.io.IOException
      Method to calculate the length of the file path.Windows 7 operating systems generally have a technical restriction of 260 characters or less for file paths. So a file path that is greater than 250 characters it can be a worry - especially if the files are to be zipped up and transferred to a Windows 7 machine.
      Parameters:
      f - File for which the path length is returned.
      Returns:
      int
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If encountered.

    • getFilePathLength

      Parameters:
      f - File.
      dir - File.
      Returns:
      int
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If encountered.

    • createNewFile

      public java.io.File createNewFile() throws java.io.IOException
      Returns a newly created file in directory returned by Generic_Files.getGeneratedDir().

      Returns:
      The File created.
      Throws:

    • createNewFile

      public java.io.File createNewFile​(java.io.File dir, java.lang.String prefix, java.lang.String suffix) throws java.io.IOException
      Returns a newly created File (which may be a directory).
      Parameters:
      dir - The directory into which the new File is to be created.
      prefix - The first part of the filename.
      suffix - The last part of the filename.
      Returns:
      The file of a newly created file in dir. The name of the file will begin with prefix and end with suffix. If a file already exists with a name which is just the prefix appended to the suffix, then a number is inserted between these two parts of the filename. The first number tried is 0, the number then increases by 1 each try.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If dir exists and is not a directory.
